element_texts.text: Completed

Dear Sherwood: I got your letter with the check and thank you for it. About the watercolor of  "Bather? it is surely alright with me to sell that for 25.00 but I want you to keep it if you want to. There is enough money now to live a good long time. I hope we can make it at Bel Air on between 30.00 and 40.00 a month I feel very much what you said that the best way to do is to sell things and speed them out for whatever money one can get. I like that idea better than cracking them with a show. Somehow from going around to galleries and what contact I have had with the art world I feel a hard cut throat atmosphere there. Of course some of that is timidity and I think in time I ought to brave the bines? den but the other way suits me fine. If with the start you have given the thing a handed widen? out it would be grand. I am sending you a watercolor I did last spring at at Bel Air from a window. I like the color harmonies
Completed

and the washer in it. I think I caught some of the gesture of the thing. The thing excited me when I did it! I do the same as you with pictures. I keep them hanging around for a long time and finally I have a feeling! Well that is a good painting! Or it just misses. The over?  that miss a lot don't take as long. I have read " Lady Chatterley's Lover". I liked it very much. It certainly is a big step toward washing off the filth that Christianity and the Plato type of mind have piled on sex. And he has avoided that other step toward death. Where they talk of sez as being beautiful but ignore the physicals as mush as possible. He has gone toward it openly and without gloves on. I think Lawrence was unable to find any solution to the obstacles in a manic? way. I am very confused but I thought?about that way. Something is wrong. There us something dead and heavy about most human life. As Lawrence said there is too much cold hearted fucking going on and money and power are a the root if a hell of a lot of it. You know it kind of astonished me.
Completed

when I first met you that you despised cleverness or in other words worldly capabilities. Somehow I felt that all people who had cracked thru despised incapability. I liked it in "Lady Chatterley's Lover" that he didn't make Mellor's a superhuman, Both he and Connie had a lot of humanness. I remember in the first letter I ever wrote you I told you how I moving? back and forth between the Christian ideal and Pagan light and color. It is time that the Pagan world backed something. They had little feeling for another human being as such. They were as hard hearted as stones. I think above all the mess Christianity or some other force has brought a human warmth into the world! Maybe this 2000 years was a step in mas growth. Lawrence and you have that warmth added to the Pagan joy of the flesh and senses. Since I met you and talked with you I am no longer ashamed to be tender. I think perhaps you have the right idea about selling the farm. An artist really hasn't any business with property that requires looking after. It tends to become a burden. I am pretty disorganized right now mentally. I will be awfully
Completed

glad to get to painting again. I don't really live when I am not working. My mind gets confused and I get irritable. I have things mostly crated and Koch's? brother Joe in coming for us next Monday in a car. God what a load possessions are and still they seem necessary. I have a craving to settle down for a while. I expect tho that I never will find a place where I am satisfied. I hope you have a good time as the seashore. Kach sends her love. With love, Charles
Completed

Thurs 1930 31
Dear Sherwood: I should have written you long ago but I have been dog tired every night. I don't like to write any one when I am that way. It colors all my thoughts. I found out the walls would require three coats of paint and it has been a lot of work. Tuesday ought to see the end of it. The living room is green and with those red chinty curtains it will seeing? Mr. Peery furnished the paint and all it cost me was the work. The diy effect color has on aperson will make the job worth while. Lord I will be glad to get moved. You knew we are staying in the big home with Kochi foche?. You need to speak of people doing
Completed

things to houses and rooms. You should be in this one for a while. There is some deadly sort of weight in every room. Once I get into our house and start painting I can keep clean. You have a great need of people but to composite? it you are able to go toward people much more easily than John or I. I can get a lot from people if I don't get too close to them. Once in a great while I meet a person I can get close to. Sometimes I think our manners are much too loose for our good. If there were traditional and formal models of intercourse established between people it would enable one to associate with and enjoy another person without getting too close before one really knows them. Perhaps the breaking down of social form? is a step in destroying mans privacy and individuality and preparing
Completed

him to be a part of machine socialism. A lot of people think of social forms as destroying individuality but it is possible that they are needed as a protection. All living people are egoists and as a rule when they get too close they do things to one another. Nature really represents to me people and the life of the universe combined. I hardly even paint a landscape where there isn't a house or some suggestion of people. I argued with you about it at symremans? and it makes Kach and me mad when I say it but I don't believe a permanent sex relations is possible between a man and a woman. It has to evolve into something else. I don't think marriage with the idea of sexual faithfulness will ever work. But
Completed

isn't it the Bible says " it is not good for man to live alone", It is true and I think marriage to be good must be sort of an [association?]] of a man and woman to voyage alone together. You spoke once of a life consisting? of moments. Mine has been like that too. I make sex a part of marriage is charming and feeling such? moment before it comes. Of course it is next? to impossible ? to get away with loving freely in the world today. One just has to plunge? along and leg it? for life the best one cane. Somehow no matter what the circumstances it overcame today? the individual filtered? against the world in the effort to live freely. I think the way you need people you are of against a world? thing them pain? and me. It seems relatives? can get garnished? up so much some that? nature. Sometimes when I look around and think
Completed

of things it seems that the only sanity in the world is in a good painting. When I happen to have a good day at work there is nothing like the balance and clear harmony I get inside. I hope to get there summer?. I care? would like to see you this fall. Kach and I would love to have you come to the home and stay any time?. There? is no care? handling this situation I have? with kid gloves. Or of you wanted I can come to Baltimore to see you. Anyway whatever your movements are you can arrange what you wish. Kach says to give you her love. With love, Charles
Completed

Dear John, It is awfully nice of  you to offer to come and get me. I would like to come but I can't right now. Right now the situation is such that it is a life and death matter to get or some sort of an independent footing. My painting got worse and worse this winter and finally I got to the point where I just couldn't go on. I am working now on a thing I will try and sell to a syndicate. I am writing up the derivation and growth of words and illustrating each one with a pen and ink? drawing. If that doesn't sell I will try something else. It is strange. You can't get away from yourself. Several years
Completed

ago I made two linoleum cuts. They had a certain black and white color. As I make more pen and ink drawings they tend to have that same black and white color. After working with black and white all day colors seem very brilliant and [singing]. After working with pen and ink me? day I come down and sat in the dining room. That pot of zinnias of yours was like a drink of rich heady wine. It has been cold and the trees are late leaving? out. I think that that first delicate green is one of the most beautiful things. I am going to paint a few water colors when that comes. I was surprised to hear of Mimi. I wish her every happiness. Charles. Summer 1932.
Completed

Dear Sherwood: You don't know what a lifesaver that money is. We were down to out last 30 dollars and half of that due on a grocery bill. The thought of money has been like a spectre hovering over my head. As a last resort I guess we could borrow from Mr. [Perry?]. He has been very nice and given us loads of things but somehow the thought of being absolutely dependent on him did things to me. I felt as if my independence would be gone. This money will take me to September when that mail elam? should come and then I will know just where I stand. Now I can paint this summer feeling free and as if I had a right to paint. Last Friday I was down to a little stream near here with a red bridge. John knows the place.
Completed

It thrilled me to my toes and I made up my mind to get it in paint if I had to work all summer and next on it. The thought of working on it without money haunting me fills me with joy. It is a very complicated thing. The stream running along among rocks and late of reflections on among the surface and on either side a mass of banked foliage with sunlight playing thru. The richness of color and light is beyond words. I will certainly send a painting to Maurice Long Jr. right away as soon as varnish will dry for the one I want to send needs a coat of varnish. It certainly was nice of him and you to do that with the clothes. He must be something like his father. I wish I could see some of John's portraits. His color is something to get up and shout about. It isn't just sensual?
Completed

but something big and stimulating. We have seen a good deal of Dorothea this spring. She thinks John is one of the finest persons she has ever met and she is pretty fine herself. I put in a garden this year and I have been fascinated with it. Each day I stand and look at it and observe what everything does. When things grow fast and stretch up I get a big back?. I suppose that with all the confusion in the world of thought it is a relief to get back to our roots. But even so I can't explain the deep satisfaction I get out of growing things in my garden. It is deeply rooted in most people I guess for the spring gardener is a stock job? in the magazines. Speaking of confessions. Ain't the world in a muddle? I can't think my way thru it all. The
Completed
only thing I can do is hang on to the few permanent things I know and wait for my head to clear. I hope I live long enough to understand this time. With love, Charles
Completed

Dear Sherwood: It was good to get your letter. Somehow I got the idea you had gone to Russia. I hope to God [[Romain Rollands?] efforts accomplish something. It is amazing with the last war fresh in our minds that we should still head for a new one. It is a hard thing tho to decide. If other nations feel warlike and bullying you don't want to be caught with your pants down but I think that military training and preparedness tends to feed that same warlike aggressive spirit. These loud mouthed generals with their shallow patriotism give me a pain. I have had rather a good summer. I am not completely satisfied with any canvas but I
Completed

feel much clearer as to what I want and the way to go after it. If a man could once get that supreme flickers of life on a canvas I guess he would be so drunk and so satisfied that he would do nothing but look at what he had done. The government got economical and consolidated the three mail router here into tow so that shut me out of the mail job. There is no work to be had so I just go on painting and somehow we manage to live along. Kach has made herself my business manager. She went to a couple of department stores to try and get them to sell paintings. They were interested but didn't want to do anything until fall. She is to see them all again soon. I am going to send four water colors
Completed

to the Watercolor Club show  in Baltimore Oct. 5 and then there is a Friends of Art show in January and I may get some things in the Little Gallery of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia. Out of all of it I may make a sale or two. John Levieweaver? brought a watercolor for a wedding present. He has been nice. I think I will send him a couple to show around later. Kach's father bought an oil for 50.00 for a wedding present and is going to buy two more to give to two men in a trust company in Philadelphia who have given him a lot of business. I guess that down in my soul I am glad I can't get other work to do. I have gone around but inside there is a not much will. As long as I can paint I don't
Completed

much care. Kach is beginning to feel the lack of money naturally since she hasn't painting to compensate her?. She craves more excitement and more people than she gets out here. Altogether the solitary artists life doesn't appeal to her much anymore. But you can't change boats in the middle of the stream. I am very anxious to see the novel. Mail Girls was a very beautiful thing. Such a lovely light in it. That is the way the beauty of it struck? me - as a tone or kind of light. That "Interview with Hoover" had the same thing in it. So damn few critics? really get your writing. They talk of form and Freudian psychology but what really matters to me is the beautiful way you see those girls. There
Completed

is a sadness in those cramped and thwarted lives but somehow you make it beautiful without lying about it. I'll bet John is happy in his house. There is something about living in a home to yourself that is much better than a room. What he told me of the view from his yard made my mouth water. I wish I could see his work. The flowers he gave Hack are lovely glowing things. If you know ahead any timne
